entry.title: Optimizing Your Sales Pipeline with Lead and Opportunity Management
entry.content:
A healthy sales pipeline doesn’t happen by chance. It’s built through clear processes, consistent execution, and the ability to focus on the right deals at the right time. For organizations selling across multiple countries and regions, local requirements matter just as much as sales fundamentals; formats for addresses and phone numbers, local languages, currencies, and data privacy obligations can all impact lead quality, conversion, and forecast reliability.

To support sales teams in achieving this, SAP Sales Cloud provides powerful capabilities for managing leads and opportunities across the entire sales cycle, from initial capture to deal closure and forecasting, while accommodating regional requirements. Features such as multi-language user interfaces, localized date/number/currency formats, country-specific address validation, territory and org structures, and consent capture help global teams operate consistently without losing local compliance and context.

The learning asset “Optimizing the Sales Pipeline through Lead and Opportunity Management” guides you through the core concepts and best practices that help sales teams work more efficiently and make smarter decisions.

In this asset, you’ll learn how to:

  • Structure and manage leads to improve qualification and conversion.
  • Prioritize opportunities using guided selling and intelligent insights.
  • Gain better visibility into pipeline health and forecast accuracy.
  • Support consistent execution across sales teams.

For multinational sales organizations, consider these practical localization tips as you apply the learning:

  • Standardize lead intake with country-aware formats (names, addresses, phone) and enable de-duplication that respects local variations.
  • Localize guided selling content and playbooks to reflect local buying processes, languages, and regulations.
  • Calibrate lead and opportunity scoring with region-specific data so models remain relevant across markets.
  • Configure currencies and exchange rates to ensure pipeline and forecasts reflect local deal values with accurate group-level rollups.
  • Capture and manage consent according to regional data protection laws (for example, opt-in and retention policies), and avoid storing unnecessary personal data.
  • Harmonize stage definitions and forecasting categories globally, while allowing approved local adaptations that preserve comparability.

Access and Requirements:

  • Access link: Optimizing the Sales Pipeline through Lead and Opportunity Management.
  • Prerequisites: A valid S-user ID and an active SAP Enterprise Support subscription are required to access the content.

Whether you’re looking to improve pipeline quality, increase win rates, or strengthen forecasting confidence, this learning provides practical guidance to help you get more value from SAP Sales Cloud, at global scale and with local precision.

Want to know more?

Explore the SAP CX Value Map combines expert-led guidance with self-paced learning materials:

  • Blogs and Articles – Stay up to date with the latest enablement stories, tips, and insights from SAP experts.
  • Event Calendar – Join live sessions, webinars, and workshops designed to help you learn directly from specialists.
  • Learning Journeys – Build your skills step-by-step through structured, role-based learning.
  • Best Practices and Guides – Access ready-to-use materials that simplify complex CX topics.
  • Continuous Quality Check (CQC) Services – Keep your SAP CX systems running efficiently.
 
About the author: 

Edmar Rodríguez is a Topic Expert for SAP Enterprise Support value maps, specializing in SAP Customer Experience. With 12 years of experience at SAP and a background spanning roles in various customer support positions, Edmar is passionate about helping customers succeed through SAP Enterprise Support offerings.

entry.title: Release Navigator for Supply Chain Management - What's New in 2602
entry.content:
Welcome to the 2026 Supply Chain Management Community!

We’re excited to share the latest enhancements coming to the Release Navigator for Supply Chain Management, including new enablement content and expanded product coverage. Our newest update occur over the next few weeks, finalizing on February 20, 2026, bringing you fresh resources designed to help you get the most value from each release.

 

Tool Overview

The Release Navigator for Supply Chain Management, provided through SAP Enterprise Support, is your central hub for understanding and managing new software releases across the supply chain portfolio.

This resource enables you to:

  • Easily explore release content through an organized, intuitive interface.
  • Quickly locate relevant materials, including updates, tools, and documentation for your SAP solutions.
  • Access guided enablement, such as webinars, workshops, and training modules, to help you fully adopt new features and meet your operational goals.

We welcome your ideas for future enhancements—share your suggestions using our brief, anonymous two‑question survey.

 

New Products

With the 2602 update, we’re pleased to introduce SAP Logistics Management into the Release Navigator.

SAP Logistics Management is a cloud-based logistics solution that unifies warehouse and transportation management to streamline operations through network‑centric collaboration. You can now explore the latest features, innovations, and enablement materials directly within the Release Navigator.

 

Content Insights

Supply Chain Management includes a wide spectrum of products, and staying aligned with the latest documentation can be challenging. To make this easier, we’ve compiled a summary of the newest and continuously updated content available to you.

Innovation Schedule

To ensure a smooth user experience, the Release Navigator introduces new user‑experience updates once per year in August, alongside refreshed release content.

The Release Navigator will update automatically over the coming weeks—no action is required on your end.

entry.title: Re: Mass Download Of Attachment In SAP Document / Invoice - SAP S4HANA / FICO
entry.content:
Great question, and an important distinction to call out.

The approach described here (using SRGBTBREL + SO tables and GUI_DOWNLOAD*) works very well for S/4HANA On‑Premise and Private Cloud systems where GOS / SAPoffice attachments are still used and direct backend access is available.

For S/4HANA Cloud (Public Edition) or scenarios where attachments are stored in SAP Document Management Service (DMS) on BTP, this approach would not apply directly due to:
• No access to SO* tables
• No GUI_DOWNLOAD
• Strict API‑based access only

In Cloud/DMS cases, mass download typically requires:
• DMS APIs / CMIS APIs
• SAP BTP-based extraction tools
• Or controlled exports via Integration Suite

So in summary:
✔️ Best suited for On‑Prem / Private Cloud with GOS
❌ Not directly applicable for Public Cloud / DMS‑only landscapes

It would be interesting to see a Part‑2 covering DMS‑based mass extraction patterns on BTP — that’s an area many customers struggle with today.

entry.title: Re: Attachment issue in Delivery
entry.content: Writing the PDF to TOAAT alone is not sufficient for Delivery attachments. GOS visibility requires a valid SRGBTBREL entry for BUS2032 (Delivery) with correct VBELN formatting (ALPHA) and RELTYPE = ATTA. If the attachment appears via manual GOS upload, the repository setup is fine and the issue is the missing GOS linkage in code. Using CL_BINARY_RELATION=>CREATE_LINK or ARCHIV_CONNECTION_INSERT during upload usually resolves this.

entry.title: Re: Clarification about storage path- GOS_ATTACHMENT_LIST...
entry.content: +1 to this. In non‑content server setups, SOFFCONT1 is the table that actually stores the binary data for GOS attachments. SRGBTBREL only maintains the business object link, while SOOD/SOFM hold header and metadata. Storage growth is usually driven silently by SOFFCONT1, so checking its size in DB02 is the right first step before any cleanup.

entry.title: Re: GST Partner needs additional fields for MM and FI inv...
entry.content:
SAP does not provide a dedicated standard field in MIRO/FB60 to capture the original GST supplier’s invoice number and date when using GST Partner.
The standard approach is to use existing reference fields (such as XBLNR or XREF1/XREF2) for reconciliation.
If those fields are already consumed, then a small, controlled enhancement (BAdI / screen enhancement) is the only clean option.
This is consistent with SAP’s design where payment vendor and GST supplier can differ, and additional metadata must be handled via references or extensions.

entry.title: Re: Analysis for Office insert Datasource dialog only shows queries. InfoProviders not showing.
entry.content:
I found the issue:
RSADMIN Table setting DFT_QUERY_CDS_SUPPORTED was configured in DS4 for testing, but not QS4.

SAP no longer fully supports the generation of default queries over data providers CUBE/DIMENSION.
2745251 - SAP S/4HANA: Deactivation of standard queries for Virtual Data Model InfoProviders

Solution is to just build an Analytical Query over the Dimension CDS View and report from that. 
SAP made this change not to utilize "Default Queries" due to potential data access issues where users are exposed to all fields of the provider instead of the explicit fields of an Analytical Query.  

Hope this helps the cause.  Thanks for the help.

entry.title: Custom fields added to extended SEGW OData entity not available in metadata
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

In Fiori App ID: F0843 (Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document), we are trying to add some custom fields in entity GR4PO_DL_Item of OData service MMIM_GR4PO_DL_SRV by redefinition and importing properties that are already available as an .include in the line item type MMIM_GR4PO_DL_ITEM.

After this we redefined "Define" method of MPC_EXT class with code:

  METHOD define.

  super->define( ).

  DATA(lo_entity_type) = model->get_entity_type( iv_entity_name = 'GR4PO_DL_Item' ).

  " Expand the specific include structure to expose its fields
  lo_entity_type->add_auto_expand_include(
    EXPORTING
      iv_include_name     = 'MMIM_GR4PO_DL_ITEM'
      iv_bind_conversions = abap_true
  ).
ENDMETHOD.

We followed the same approach as shown in this learning journey:

https://learning.sap.com/courses/building-odata-services-with-sap-gateway/redefining-an-sap-gateway-service

We already generated the Runtime objects and there seems to be no error as metadata loading properly. However, in the metadata the custom fields are not available and we are not sure what could be missing. The metadata does show the all the inlcudes but does not show the fields added to include, even though they are available in extended entity type.

Did someone face similar situation and can help in finding the solution?

entry.title: Linked analysis based on widgets having different data sources with no common dimension-Part 2
entry.content:
Introduction

In SAP Analytics Cloud, stories use widgets like charts and tables to visualize data from various models. While Linked Analysis typically enables dynamic interactions between widgets sharing a common dimension, it natively fails when data sources are unrelated. 

This document explores how to implement custom Linked Analysis between widgets based on different data sources with no common dimensions by using scripting within SAC Analytics Designer (now part of the unified SAP Analytics Cloud Story experience).

Dive Further in the SAC Application

In the previous blog, we created Application where requirement was to populate page with default features as below.

Link to the previous blog Linked analysis based on widgets having different ... - SAP Community

Now we will enhance application created in previous blog with below.

  • Users should be able to select Company Code from Dropdown 1, Dropdown 2 should show Division corresponding to Selected Company Code in Dropdown 1 and on click on Button, corresponding result should show.
  • If selected Node is FI_ACT12 then Country dropdown should be available otherwise it should not be displayed and If selected Node is FI_ACT6 then there should be Axis swap between Rows and Columns
  • If Selected Activity Type is “C” from Fact table, then only Popup message should come

We will need additional model of Country and one Popup to achieve our requirement in addition to objects already created in previous blog.

Table, Model required  under the blog  in SAC Application

  • Table_4 corresponds to Country Model
  • Popup with Message “Popup has been opened as required condition has met” and a button to close

Achieving additional features as part of Enhancement of SAC application

a. Users should be able to select Company Code from Dropdown 1, Dropdown 2 should show Division corresponding to Selected Company Code in Dropdown 1 and on click on Button, corresponding result should show

Step 1.

Below Steps needs to be written on onSelect of Dropdown_1 which corresponds to Company code to populate corresponding Divisions

//Get all values from the table 3 with list of Company codes

 var resultSet = Table_3.getDataSource().getResultSet();

// Get Company Code selected by user

var cCode = Dropdown_1.getSelectedKey();

//Remove all items in the Division  dropdown

Dropdown_2.removeAllItems();

// Fill only Division relevant to selected Company

for ( var j = 0; j< resultSet.length; j++ ){  

              if ( resultSet[j]["Company_Code"].id === cCode ){

Dropdown_2.addItem(resultSet[j]["Division"].id,resultSet[j]["Division"].description);     }}

Step 2.

Write script on the onClick event of button(description of each step has been added as comment)

var cc = Dropdown_1.getSelectedKey();  //Company code selected

var division = Dropdown_2.getSelectedKey(); //Division selected

var period = Dropdown_3.getSelectedKey(); //Period selected

//Apply Company code, division and Period filter on Table 2 which contain Fact data

 Table_2.getDataSource().setDimensionFilter("CompanyCode",cc);

Table_2.getDataSource().setDimensionFilter("Period",period);

Table_1.getDataSource().setDimensionFilter("Division", division);

b). If selected Node is FI_ACT12 then Country dropdown should be available otherwise it should not be displayed and If selected Node is FI_ACT6 then there should be Axis swap between Rows and Columns

Step 1.

Write script on onSelect of Table 1(description of each step has been added as comment)

//dropdown 4 logic

//Country dropdown Creation

var resultSet_country =  Table_4.getDataSource().getResultSet();

 for(var j=0; j<resultSet_country.length; j++)   {

//Show ID and description: resultSet_country[j]["Country"].id will show ID and resultSet_country[j]["Country"].id +" " +resultSet_country[j]["Country"].description shows text

                             Dropdown_4.addItem(resultSet_country[j]["Country"].id,resultSet_country[j]["Country"].id +" "   +resultSet_country[j]["Country"].description );    }

//If selected Node is FI_ACT12 then Country dropdown should be available otherwise should not be //displayed

//This statement will fetch the selected Node

var node = this.getSelections()[0]["IDs"];

if (node === "FI_ACT12") {

Dropdown_4.setVisible(true);}

              else{

                             Dropdown_4.setVisible(false);}; 

Step 2.

// If selected Node is FI_ACT6 then there should be Axis swap between Rows and Columns

if ( node === "FI_ACT6" )    {

Table_2.addDimensionToColumns("IDs",1);

Table_2.addDimensionToColumns("ActType",2);

Table_2.addDimensionToColumns("Period",3);

Table_2.addDimensionToRows("Country",1);

Table_2.removeDimension("CompanyCode");}

c).If Selected Activity Type is “C” from Fact table, then only Popup message should come

Write script on onSelect of Table 2(description of each step has been added as comment)

var rowType = this.getSelections()[0]["ActType"];

if (rowType === "C") {  Popup_1.open();}; 

After applying above logic, the Page comes as expected.

Testing of the all  Logic added to SAC Application

1.If selected Node is FI_ACT12 then Country dropdown should be available otherwise it should not be displayed

2.If selected Node is FI_ACT6 then there should be Axis swap between Rows and Columns

3.If Selected Activity Type is “C” from Fact table, then a Popup should come else not

 

 

Conclusion

We can get the Linked analysis like features using SAC scripting. This document could help in many scenarios where similar requirement is there with bit of additional script.

entry.title: Re: Why are self-joins designed for tables in SAP Universe
entry.content:
I'm not sure I understand your question.  In looking at your SQL, it is not technically a self join but an alias of the AOR table joined to another alias of the AOR table.  In universes, a self join appears as a join but is just a condition forced every time the table is referenced in a query.

The join in your SQL implies that the AOR table has multiple levels of detail.  your case, the AORFCT_SHIPMENT_UNION_V as multiple detail levels about the shipment using the same SHIPMENT_KEY.  The way query is set up, you will only get the rows where STT_NB='xxxxxxx' from the FACT_SHIPMENT alias and you will get ALL of the details of the shipment, including when STT_NB='xxxxxxx' from the FACT_SHIPMENT_METRICS.  I don't know the business need but it seems to me you might want an additional condition to limit FACT_SHIPMENT_METRICS <> 'xxxxxxx'.

If this seems to answer your question, kindly mark this as an Accepted Solution.  If not, please provide more details and I'll give it my best effort.

entry.title: Working with BW Authorizations in Datasphere on Enterprise Level
entry.content:
Related resources

  • Blog Post: Introducing Remote Authorizations from SAP BW/4HANA for SAP Datasphere 
  • Blog Post by @Martin_Kuma: BW-Like Authorizations in Datasphere (DSP) 
  • Documentation: Import SAP BW and SAP BW∕4HANA Analysis Authorizations 
  • Note: 3062381

 

Why resolve BW authorizations in Datasphere?

In enterprise analytics SAP Datasphere often needs to federates the SAP BW analysis authorization table RSDWC_RSEC_DAC to data access controls (DAC). We build on this SAP standard (no custom BW developments are required beyond generation/extraction of the standard table) and bring the resolution step into the HANA layer for scale and performance.

Performance matters: The default runtime-only resolution evaluates long WHERE predicate strings per session user and iterates them at query time. With many users and complex rules, that becomes inperformant and unpredictable in terms of latency. By pre‑resolving per objectinto a persisted table we decouple expensive checks from BI queries, achieve consistent, auditable results, and enable scheduled refreshes.

 

Prerequisites

  1. RSDWC_RSEC_DAC as a Remote Table in Datasphere. Generate/refresh it in BW with transaction RSDWC_DAC_RSEC_GEN and the BAdI RSDWC_DAC_RSEC_USER_UPDATE (and optionally schedule report RSDWC_DAC_RSEC_EXTRACT). The table can then be exposed to Datasphere. 
  2. A HANA DB user (Open SQL schema) in Datasphere. This user owns the Function, Procedure and Table and is granted to the space technical user to run in Task Chains.
  3. Optional: an Entities/"booked values" table/view. Applying predicates to the set of actually booked combinations avoids generating all possible cross‑combinations which can be a huge performance multiplier and inflate result sizes.

 

Where our default approaches falls short

  • Runtime resolution per current user leads to high CPU/time due to long predicate strings.
  • SQL views in Datasphere lack loops/cursors; scaling to many users is cumbersome.
  • Duplicating views per user and UNION them is not maintainable and limits parallelization.

 

Example at a glance

In this blog’s walkthrough OBJECT01 is our authorization object that groups the key BW characteristics used for data access in the BWAUTH02 mapping. Concretely, OBJECT01 controls combinations of the following standard InfoObjects:

  • /BIC/0COMP_CODE (Company Code)
  • /BIC/0PLANT (Plant)
  • /BIC/0SALESORG (Sales Organization)
  • /BIC/0PROFIT_CTR (Profit Center)
  • /BIC/0CS_PLEVEL

The SAP standard table RSDWC_RSEC_DAC (federated as a remote table to Datasphere) holds per BW user and per object the dynamic WHERE‑predicate string that expresses allowed values/ranges for these characteristics.

 

Solution overview: Function + Procedure + Table + Task Chain + View

We implement five building blocks in an Open SQL schema and orchestrate them from Datasphere:

  1. Table Function `TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02`: reads normalized WHERE predicate from RSEC view and applies it to booked entities via `APPLY_FILTER`.
  2. Procedure `SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02`: loops over all BW users for OBJECT01 and persists the union of results into a target table (full refresh).
  3. Persisted table `AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02`: mirrors function output for /BIC/0* fields.
  4. View `GV_AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02`: exposes the table for DACs and downstream pipelines.
  5. Task Chain `TC_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02`: schedules the refresh procedure regularly.

Source artifacts and naming

  • RSEC (clean) view: "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_RSDWC_RSEC_DAC_BWAUTH02" (column FILTERFIELDNM holds the normalized predicate)
  • Entities view (booked combinations): "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_OBJECT01_DAC_ENTITIES_BOOKED_BWAUTH02"
  • Target table: "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02"
  • Exposing view: "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02"
  • Task Chain: TC_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02

Target table 

CREATE COLUMN TABLE "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02" (
    "User"             NVARCHAR(256),
    "OBJECTNAME"       NVARCHAR(40),
    "/BIC/0PLANT"      NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0SALESORG"   NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL"  NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR" NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"  NVARCHAR(20)
);

Table Function 

/* --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   Object:   FUNCTION "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02"
   Purpose:  For a given BW user, returns the authorized ENTITY combinations
             for OBJECT01 (fixed here; can be parameterized later).
             The WHERE predicate string is read dynamically from the RSEC view
             and applied to the Entities view via APPLY_FILTER.

   Input:    P_USER (NVARCHAR(256)) – BWUSERID for which the authorization resolution is executed.

   Output:   Result set with the following columns (aligned to the new standard InfoObjects):
             "User", "OBJECTNAME",
             "/BIC/0PLANT", "/BIC/0SALESORG", "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL",
             "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR", "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"

   Assumptions & behavior:
     - Exactly ONE record exists in the RSEC view for (BWUSERID = P_USER, OBJECTNAME = 'OBJECT01_BWAUTH02').
       -> SELECT ... INTO expects exactly 1 row. More than one -> "row not unique"; none -> "no data found".
     - INFOOBJ is intentionally fixed to 'OBJECT01_BWAUTH02' for this scenario.
     - APPLY_FILTER expects a syntactically valid WHERE string (without the "WHERE" keyword).

   Security/runtime:
     - SQL SECURITY INVOKER: Privilege checks are executed in the caller's context.
       -> Caller must have SELECT on the views used in the space/schema.
     - APPLY_FILTER is safer than EXEC/EXECUTE IMMEDIATE regarding SQL injection,
       however FILTERFIELDNM must be maintained reliably in the RSEC view.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
CREATE FUNCTION "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02"(
    IN P_USER NVARCHAR(256)
)
RETURNS TABLE (
    "User"           NVARCHAR(256),
    "OBJECTNAME"     NVARCHAR(40),
    "/BIC/0PLANT"    NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0SALESORG" NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL" NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR" NVARCHAR(20),
    "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"  NVARCHAR(20)
)
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
SQL SECURITY INVOKER
AS
BEGIN
    /* Local variables:
       - FILTER_CLAUSE: holds the dynamic WHERE predicate read from the RSEC view
       - INFOOBJ: fixed to OBJECT01 (current scenario)
    */
    DECLARE FILTER_CLAUSE NCLOB;
    DECLARE INFOOBJ NVARCHAR(40);

    /* Fixed authorization object; can be modeled as IN parameter if needed */
    INFOOBJ = 'OBJECT01';

    /* 1) Load filter string for the user.
          Expects exactly one match. If SELECT returns 0 or >1 rows, HANA raises an exception.
          This should be ensured in the RSEC view content. */
    SELECT FILTERFIELDNM
      INTO FILTER_CLAUSE
      FROM "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_RSDWC_RSEC_DAC_BWAUTH02"
     WHERE BWUSERID   = :P_USER
       AND OBJECTNAME = INFOOBJ;

    /* 2) APPLY_FILTER:
          - Applies the dynamic WHERE expression to the entities view.
          - The result is materialized in the implicit table variable lt_result. */
    lt_result = APPLY_FILTER(
        "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_OBJECT01_DAC_ENTITIES_BOOKED_BWAUTH02",
        :FILTER_CLAUSE
    );

    /* 3) Assemble result:
          - DISTINCT -> avoid duplicates.
          - P_USER and INFOOBJ are carried as constant columns. */
    RETURN
    SELECT DISTINCT
        :P_USER    AS "User",
        INFOOBJ    AS "OBJECTNAME",
        "/BIC/0PLANT",
        "/BIC/0SALESORG",
        "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL",
        "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR",
        "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"
    FROM :lt_result;
END;

You can check how it is working: 

SELECT * FROM "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02"('ABC02')

Procedure

/* --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
   Object:   PROCEDURE "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02"
   Purpose:  Full-refresh build of table "AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02":
             - Collect all BWUSERID relevant for OBJECT01 (from GV_RSDWC_RSEC_DAC_BWAUTH02)
             - For each user, call table function TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02
             - Persist the union of results into the target table

   Flow:
     1) Cursor over DISTINCT BWUSERID from the RSEC view (OBJECTNAME = 'OBJECT01')
     2) DELETE the target table (clear all rows for a full rebuild)
     3) FOR-loop: INSERT ... SELECT from the table function for each user

   Security:
     - SQL SECURITY INVOKER: privilege checks run in caller context
     - Caller requires:
       * SELECT on source RSEC view
       * INSERT/DELETE on target table

   Performance:
     - Loop calls the TF once per user (N calls).
       For large N, consider a set-based approach (bulk table function) later.

   Notes:
     - INSERT lists columns explicitly to guard against future schema changes
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
CREATE PROCEDURE "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02" ()
LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT
SQL SECURITY INVOKER
AS
BEGIN

  /* 1) Cursor: distinct list of relevant users for OBJECT01 */
  DECLARE CURSOR cur_users FOR
    SELECT DISTINCT BWUSERID
      FROM "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_RSDWC_RSEC_DAC_BWAUTH02"
     WHERE OBJECTNAME = 'OBJECT01'
       AND BWUSERID   IS NOT NULL;

  /* 2) Full rebuild: clear target table */
  DELETE FROM "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02";

  /* 3) Implicit FOR-loop: HANA opens/closes the cursor automatically */
  FOR cur_row AS cur_users DO

    INSERT INTO "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02"
      ( "User", "OBJECTNAME",
        "/BIC/0PLANT", "/BIC/0SALESORG", "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL",
        "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR", "/BIC/0COMP_CODE" )
    SELECT
        "User", "OBJECTNAME",
        "/BIC/0PLANT", "/BIC/0SALESORG", "/BIC/0CS_PLEVEL",
        "/BIC/0PROFIT_CTR", "/BIC/0COMP_CODE"
    FROM "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."TF_AUTH_RESOLVE_OBJECT01_BWAUTH02"( :cur_row.BWUSERID );

  END FOR;

END;

Execute via Task Chain step or manually:

CALL "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02"();
SELECT * FROM "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02";

Security, view exposure, and task chain

  • Create Datasphere view: "DEMO_AR_001"."GV_AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02" over the table to feed DACs and downstream processes. 

  • Schedule a Task Chain "TC_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02" that calls the procedure for regular refresh.

To add the procedure your user needs to be granted: 

-- Minimal grants (adapt to your technical user / space)
GRANT EXECUTE ON PROCEDURE "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."SP_AUTH_OBJECT01_REFRESH_BWAUTH02" TO "DEMO_AR_001";
GRANT SELECT, INSERT, DELETE ON "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01"."AUTH_OBJECT01_RESULT_BWAUTH02" TO "DEMO_AR_001";
-- Optional: schema-wide
GRANT EXECUTE ON SCHEMA "DEMO_AR_001#HDB_USER01" TO "DEMO_AR_001" WITH GRANT OPTION;

If you do not know the needed Schema: 

SELECT SCHEMA_NAME, SCHEMA_OWNER
FROM SYS.SCHEMAS

 

Performance & scalability

  • Pre-resolving moves string evaluation out of query-time; persisted results enable indexes and faster joins.
  • Keep the entities view "booked" to avoid generating all combinations (Cartesian blow-up).
  • For very large user counts, consider a set-based bulk table function to avoid N function calls.

 

Troubleshooting

  • Error 260 invalid column name: fix duplicated /BIC/ prefixes or mismatched InfoObject names.
  • No data found / row not unique: enforce exactly 1 row per (BWUSERID, OBJECTNAME) in RSEC view.
  • Permissions: INVOKER needs SELECT on sources and INSERT/DELETE on target; scheduler user needs EXECUTE on procedure.

 

What you get

A maintainable, enterprise-ready pattern to pre-resolve BW authorizations in SAP Datasphere, fully based on SAP standard RSDWC_RSEC_DAC: reproducible results, faster queries and a scheduling hook via Task Chains. From here, you can attach DACs to exposed views or plug the table into harmonization and governance pipelines.

entry.title: Re: U.S SECURE 2.0 Act - Section 603
entry.content:
Hi Team,

In SAP Note 3684378 – BEN: Annual limits for tax year 2026, I do not see an entry for constant 457CL (457 catch-up contribution limit) which I have seen in previous Annual Limits notes.  Usually the 457CL amount is double the 402g limit or 457 limit ($24,500 for 2026) which I presume would be $49,000 for 2026 (up from $47,000 in 2025.)

Will SAP publish any 2026 update for 457CL?  And if not, do we manually update the constant to $49,000 for 2026 or leave as-is from 2025?

Thanks,

Larry

entry.title: Why Does SAP Use the Shortage Date for Storage Cost Calculation Even After Forward Scheduling?
entry.content:
I’m working with dynamic lot sizing (lot size DY) in MRP and noticed a behavior I’m struggling to reconcile with the standard logic.

In my scenario:

  • First shortage: 15 January, 44 pcs
  • Next requirement: 6 April, 50 pcs
  • RLT: 9 April (Purchasing Processing time 4 working days + PDT 63 cal. days + GR processing time 10 work days)
  • Storage cost rate: 10%
  • Ordering Costs: 35$
  • MAP: 34.02$
  • SAP calculates 81 extra storage days (6 Apr – 15 Jan)

Because backward scheduling produced a start date in the past, SAP switched to forward scheduling. Now the material is only be available on 24 March.

My question is:

Why does the dynamic lot-sizing formula still use the shortage date (15 January) as the start of storage, instead of the actual earliest availability date (24 March)?

Storage Costs = (81 * 34.02 * 10 * 50)/36500 = 37.74$

From a logistics perspective, storage cannot begin before the material physically exists. But SAP continues to calculate extra storage days as if the product were available on the shortage date, even though the system itself determined that the requirement cannot be met until much later.

Is this the intended behavior of DY, or am I misunderstanding something here?

entry.title: Prompt to automate Design Worksheet tabs of the Compensation module workbooks
entry.content:
Introduction

The "Design worksheet" tab of Compensation workbooks contains the details of every field designed in a Compensation template and usually takes a very significant amount of time (and tedious screen comparison work) for consultants to finalize (it could also be customers wanting to update an existing workbook after they made modifications to their templates since the initial implementation - for example new integration to EC). 

While I remain hopeful that one day we will have a button in Admin Center to instantly generate workbooks for any of our HCM Suite modules, for the time being I created a Prompt for GenAI models to automatically create this Design Worksheet tab.

 

 

Pre-requisite (model file download)

This prompt works hand in hand with this Demo xls file which I built using the same exact layout than the module's official workbooks (partner authorization required for this link) and updated with the most recent settings available as of 2H 2025. I simply added an extra column (A) to simplify the prompt and make the file generate faster. Cells A1 to A37 can be deleted once the file has been generated (select > delete and move to left).

 

Screenshot of the Demo file to help GenAI models generate the output:

 

 

Prompt

 

Can you please turn the document attached into a similar workbook than the xls demo example I am attaching. Keep the first two columns A and B the same and start in column C. Important: in the Section Header row use the color code as background color for the merged cells and add the column-id of the column displayed when collapsed (if collapsed instead of expanded). Important: in the Field Name row use the same color for each column as the section header color. Columns with value "Standard-manually entered on form" should be the only ones that have two subcolumns, one for the amount, another for the percentage.

When column A = isCustomField :

  • isCustomField="false" and comp-ect-input-field-map tag missing and readOnly="true" --> "Standard-compensation field".
  • isCustomField="false" and comp-ect-input-field-map tag present --> "Standard-imported from EC or upload".
  • isCustomField="false" and readOnly="false" --> "Standard-manually entered on form".
  • isCustomField="true" and  comp-custom-field-formula tag is present --> "Custom-formula".
  • isCustomField="true" and readOnly="false" --> "Custom-manually entered on form".
  • isCustomField="true" and comp-ect-input-field-map tag present --> "Custom-imported from EC or upload".

When column A = readOnly: true --> Yes, false --> No.

When column A = type: values should be String, Money, Amount, Percent, Date or UserName.

When column A = comp-help-text: if no tag present set to "No" otherwise "Yes".

When column A = comp-help-text-message: leave blank if above line is "No", otherwise copy comp-help-text-message in the cell.

When column A = alignment: fill blank values with "default".

When column A= comp-custom-validation: enter "No" if tag is missing all together, enter "Yes" if present.

Fully remove the following columns: salaryTab, executiveRuleViolation, salaryAction, executiveAction, salaryNote, budgetPlannedTotal, moreToAllocate, budget, mgrFirstName, mgrLastName, userName.

 

 

 

Conclusion

SAP employees are only allow to use GenAI tools available through the Generative AI Lab page (lots of famous LLM models are available there) which link can be found through the SAP sharepoint site "CPIT Enterprise AI CoE" (205734) > Big Data and AI Platform > Generative AI Experience Lab.

  • Please note:
    • Some models cannot create a file based on prompts + demo file and will only be able to build Python code that will then need to be imported into a Python software to create the excel.
    • FBP groups permissions do not carry over in exported files hence cannot be automated.
    • As per introduction: Cells A1 to A37 can be deleted once the file has been generated (select > delete and move to left).

 

 

 

Best,

Xavier

 

 


(If you found this blog useful please consider giving it a Kudo)

entry.title: SAC: How to call Content Network job via API using ABAP
entry.content:
The post is a response to the lack of standard mechanisms for performing backups in SAP SAC at the model level by the user.
The inspiration was one of the scenarios considered by Max_Gander in the post:
Options to Back-up Your SAP Analytics Cloud Planni... - SAP Community

In my organization, I used the scenario Back-up model in SAP Analytics Cloud for one of the models. The reason was the longer time needed to develop an ABAP program that could call an import package in Content Network from my favorite SAP BW/4.

Below I will present the code and configuration that will allow you to call the import job in content management without using third-party tools like postman etc.

So it’s an implementation of Content Network backup scenario from the blog mentioned

1. Set Up Third-Party Access with OAuth Clients

This is the first step, which is best done according to the documentation.
Set Up Third-Party Access with OAuth Clients | SAP Help Portal

Briefly, SAC -> System->Administration->App Integration-> +Add an OAuth Client

When creating an OAuth client, the system displays the secret key only once, so don't forget to copy it

2. Set up connection in SAP BW/4

SM59 -> HTTP Connection to External Server

 

Test it

 

3. Program with all important comments

REPORT REPSACAPI.

DATA: LO_HTTP_CLIENT TYPE REF TO IF_HTTP_CLIENT,
      lo_API02 TYPE REF TO IF_HTTP_CLIENT,
      lo_API02a TYPE REF TO IF_HTTP_CLIENT.
DATA: response TYPE string,
      http_status type string,
      lv_code type i,
      reason type string.
data: lv_url type string.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_token_response,
         access_token TYPE string,
         token_type   TYPE string,
         expires_in   TYPE i,
         scope        TYPE string,
         jti          TYPE string,
       END OF ty_token_response.

DATA: ls_token_data    TYPE ty_token_response,
      lv_token         TYPE string,
      lv_atok          type string,
      lv_csrf_token    TYPE string,
      lv_body          TYPE string.


DATA: lt_headers TYPE tihttpnvp,
      ls_header  TYPE ihttpnvp,
      lt_headers01 type tihttpnvp.
DATA: lv_content_length TYPE string.

DATA: lt_cookies TYPE TABLE OF string,
      lv_cookie TYPE string,
      lv_cookie_remaining TYPE string.
DATA  lv_decoded_cookie TYPE string.


*Put your SAC hosi into lv_url_d
PARAMETERS: lv_url_d type string OBLIGATORY LOWER CASE.

******Begin:  to get <Access_Token> *****
CL_HTTP_CLIENT=>CREATE_BY_DESTINATION(
    EXPORTING
        DESTINATION = 'Your RFC name' "Name of the RFC destination
    IMPORTING
        CLIENT = LO_HTTP_CLIENT " HTTP Client object
    EXCEPTIONS
         ARGUMENT_NOT_FOUND = 1
         DESTINATION_NOT_FOUND = 2
         DESTINATION_NO_AUTHORITY = 3
         PLUGIN_NOT_ACTIVE = 4
         INTERNAL_ERROR = 5
         OTHERS = 6 ).

lo_http_client->request->set_method( if_http_request=>CO_REQUEST_METHOD_POST ).
CALL METHOD lo_http_client->send
  EXCEPTIONS
    http_communication_failure = 1
    http_invalid_state         = 2
    http_processing_failed     = 3
    http_invalid_timeout       = 4
    OTHERS                     = 5.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
  CALL METHOD lo_http_client->receive
    EXCEPTIONS
      http_communication_failure = 1
      http_invalid_state         = 2
      http_processing_failed     = 3
      OTHERS                     = 5.
ENDIF.
response = lo_http_client->response->get_cdata( ).
CALL METHOD /ui2/cl_json=>deserialize
  EXPORTING
    json = response
  CHANGING
    data = ls_token_data.
******End:  to get <Access_Token> *****

******Begin:  to get X-CSRF token *****
lv_url = LV_URL_D && '/api/v1/csrf'.
CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
  EXPORTING
 url = lv_url
  IMPORTING
    client             = lo_API02
  EXCEPTIONS
    argument_not_found = 1
    plugin_not_active  = 2
    internal_error     = 3
    OTHERS             = 4.

lo_API02->request->set_method('GET').

lv_atok  = |Bearer { ls_token_data-access_token }|.
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = lv_atok ).
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-csrf-token' value = 'fetch' ).
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-sap-sac-custom-auth' value = 'true' ).
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'DataServiceVersion' value = '2.0' ).
lo_API02->request->set_header_field( name = 'Accept' value = 'application/json' ).

CALL METHOD lo_API02->send
  EXCEPTIONS
    http_communication_failure = 1
    http_invalid_state         = 2
    http_processing_failed     = 3
    http_invalid_timeout       = 4
    OTHERS                     = 5.
IF sy-subrc = 0.
  CALL METHOD lo_API02->receive
    EXCEPTIONS
      http_communication_failure = 1
      http_invalid_state         = 2
      http_processing_failed     = 3
      OTHERS                     = 5.
ENDIF.

call method lo_API02->response->get_status
 IMPORTING
    code = lv_code
    REASON = reason.
CALL METHOD lo_API02->response->get_header_field
  EXPORTING
    name  = 'x-csrf-token'
  RECEIVING
    value = lv_csrf_token.
CALL METHOD lo_api02->response->get_header_fields
  CHANGING
    fields = lt_headers.
response = lo_API02->response->get_cdata( ).
******End:  to get X-CSRF token *****


******Begin: run the job
lv_url = LV_URL_D && '/api/v1/content/jobs'.
CALL METHOD cl_http_client=>create_by_url
  EXPORTING
 url = lv_url
  IMPORTING
    client             = lo_API02a
  EXCEPTIONS
    argument_not_found = 1
    plugin_not_active  = 2
    internal_error     = 3
    OTHERS             = 4.
lo_API02a->request->set_method('POST').

* !!! Crucial: pass cookies
LOOP AT lt_headers INTO ls_header.
  IF ls_header-name = 'set-cookie'.
    IF ls_header-value CS 'JSESSIONID='.
      SPLIT ls_header-value AT ';' INTO lv_cookie lv_cookie_remaining.
      lv_cookie = lv_cookie+11.
      EXIT.
    ENDIF.
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.

lv_decoded_cookie = cl_http_utility=>unescape_url(
                escaped   = lv_cookie ).

lv_body = '{"type": "IMPORT", "packageName": "Your Package name","privatePackage": Your Package ID,"allObjects": true}'.

lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'Authorization' value = lv_atok ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-sap-sac-custom-auth' value = 'true' ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'Connection' value = 'keep-alive' ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Type' value = 'application/json' ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'x-csrf-token' value = lv_csrf_token ).
lo_API02a->request->set_cookie( name = 'JSESSIONID' value = lv_decoded_cookie ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'X-Requested-With' value = 'XMLHttpRequest' ).

lv_content_length = strlen( lv_body ).
lo_API02a->request->set_header_field( name = 'Content-Length' value = lv_content_length ).
lo_API02a->request->set_cdata( lv_body ).

CALL METHOD lo_API02a->send
  EXCEPTIONS
    http_communication_failure = 1
    http_invalid_state         = 2
    http_processing_failed     = 3
    http_invalid_timeout       = 4
    OTHERS                     = 5.

IF sy-subrc = 0.
  CALL METHOD lo_API02a->receive
    EXCEPTIONS
      http_communication_failure = 1
      http_invalid_state         = 2
      http_processing_failed     = 3
      OTHERS                     = 5.
ENDIF.

call method lo_API02a->response->get_status
 IMPORTING
    code = lv_code
    REASON = reason.

response = lo_API02a->response->get_cdata( ).
CALL METHOD lo_API02a->close.
CALL METHOD lo_API02->close.
CALL METHOD LO_HTTP_CLIENT->close.

******End: run the job

WRITE: 'response: ', response.

 

 4. Finally you can check the result  via SAC-> Transport-> Monitor

 

Sources:

Introduction of SAC Multi-actions Public API - SAP Community

entry.title: SAP UI5 - Draft Handling in FreeStyle Applications
entry.content:
• 1. Creating a DraftManager Class
  • 1.1 Initialization
  • 1.2 Draft Functions in the DraftManager
  • 2. Instantiating the DraftManager in the Controller
  • 3. Using the DraftManager in the Controller
  • 3.1 Start Editing
  • 3.2 Save
  • 3.3 Cancel
  • 4. DraftHandling and MERGE lock errors
  • 5. Conclusion

 

1. Creating a DraftManager Class

In this post, I would like to share some of my experience with draft handling in FreeStyle applications.
After we decided in one of our projects to implement draft handling and at the same time had to consider our new component-based architecture, we encapsulated SAP’s DraftController (sap.ui.generic.app.transaction.DraftController) in a way that made sense for our use case.

I describe one possible encapsulation of the DraftController in a service class called "DraftManager", which (depending on the project) can be integrated and used across FreeStyle applications.
This approach worked very well for us, especially since official documentation was quite limited at that time.

Important: In our application we use an OData V2 service (with CDS views) that is already prepared accordingly for draft handling.

1.1 Initialization

The DraftManager is a service class used to encapsulate the DraftController.
The following basic structure has proven itself in our projects and can be used as is or adapted and extended as needed.

When initializing the DraftManager in the controller, we only pass the component instance and the view’s binding context.

(Example)

this.oDraftManager = new DraftManager(this.getOwnerComponent(), oContext);

The binding context is stored internally within the class for further processing and can be accessed or modified if required using the helper functions getActiveContext and setActiveContext.

Basic structure:

sap.ui.define([
  "sap/ui/generic/app/transaction/DraftController"
], function (DraftController) {
  "use strict";

  const DraftManager = function (oComponent, oContext) {
    this.oModel = oComponent.getModel();
    this.oDraftController = new DraftController(this.oModel);
    this.oActiveContext = oContext;
    this.oDraftContext = null;
  };

  DraftManager.prototype.setActiveContext = function (oContext) {
    this.oActiveContext = oContext;
  };

  DraftManager.prototype.getActiveContext = function () {
    return this.oActiveContext;
  };

  return DraftManager;
});

 

1.2 Draft Functions in the DraftManager

The DraftManager can be extended as needed, but in this post I would like to focus in particular on the main draft handling functions (Activate, Edit, and Discard).

Determine or Create a Draft

The DraftController itself is relatively easy to use.
However, there are operations, such as Edit, that always require multiple steps.
If a draft already exists, a new one cannot be created and an error will occur.

To avoid having to implement the same check in every controller, this logic is encapsulated.
This way, only a single function needs to be executed.

In this example code, we first check whether a draft exists for the active view context.
If so, it is returned and the controller can rebind the view accordingly.
If not, a new draft is created.

If needed, success and error messages can also be handled inside the function (for example, if they should be consistent across several applications). We use our own separate error handling in this case.

DraftManager.prototype.getOrCreateEditDraft = async function () {
  const oExistingDraft = await this.oDraftController.getDraftForActiveEntity(this.oActiveContext);

  if (oExistingDraft && !oExistingDraft.context.getObject().IsActiveEntity) {
    this.oDraftContext = oExistingDraft.context;
    return this.oDraftContext;
  }

  const oDraft = await this.oDraftController.createEditDraftEntity(this.oActiveContext);

  this.oDraftContext = oDraft.context;
  return this.oDraftContext;
};

Activate a Draft

Activating a draft is pretty straightforward in this case. Here as well: The function can be extended as needed (error + success handling e.g.)

DraftManager.prototype.activateDraft = async function () {
  await this.oDraftController.activateDraftEntity(this.oDraftContext);
  this.oActiveContext = this.oDraftContext;
};

Discard a Draft

Discarding a draft is also easy to implement in this case.

DraftManager.prototype.discardDraft = async function () {
  await this.oDraftController.discardDraft(this.oDraftContext);
  this.oDraftContext = null;
};

2. Instantiating the DraftManager in the Controller

As mentioned at the beginning, the DraftManager can be instantiated quite easily.

Example: We have a master/detail application with an onRouteMatched function in the detail controller.
Assume we have a SmartTable on the master page and navigate to the detail page after clicking on an entry.
Here, we pass the corresponding bound id (or guid) of the list item and the HasActiveEntity property.

Using this properties, we now create a raw context (helper function _loadContext) and start instantiating the DraftManager .

onRouteMatched: async function (oEvent) {
  const sId = oEvent.getParameter("arguments").UUID;
  const bActive = oEvent.getParameter("arguments").HasActiveEntity;

  try {
	const oContext = await this._loadContext("/EntitySet", { "UUID": sId, "IsActiveEntity": bActive });
	this.oDraftManager = new DraftManager(this.getOwnerComponent(), oContext);
  } catch (oError) {
	//error handling
  }  
}
_loadContext: async function (sEntity, oContextParameters) {
	const oModel = this.getView().getModel();
	await oModel.metadataLoaded();
	const sKey = oModel.createKey(sEntity, oContextParameters);
	const oContext = new sap.ui.model.Context(oModel, sKey);
	return Promise.resolve(oContext);
},

After that, the DraftManager is instantiated and can be used.

3. Using the DraftManager in the Controller

From this point on things become much more relaxed, as encapsulating the draft logic significantly reduces the number of operations in the controller.

I will keep the following examples to a minimum. Depending on the requirements, these can of course become more complex.

For rebinding/refreshing the view, we're using the following helper function:

_bindView: async function (sId, bIsActiveEntity) {
  return new Promise((resolve) => {
    this.getView().bindElement({
      path: `/EntitySet(UUID=guid'${sId}',IsActiveEntity=${bIsActiveEntity})`,
      parameters: {
        expand: "DraftAdministrativeData"
      },
      events: {
        change: (oEvent) => {
          resolve(oEvent.getSource().getBoundContext());
        }
      }
    });
  });
};

3.1 Start Editing

Editing has now become a fire-and-forget function, as everything is nicely encapsulated.
After each draft operation, the view should be updated (in this case using _bindView).

onEdit: async function () {
	try {	
		const oDraftContext = await this.oDraftManager.getOrCreateEditDraft();  
		await this._bindView(
			oDraftContext.getProperty("UUID"),
			oDraftContext.getProperty("IsActiveEntity")
		);		
	} catch (oError) {
		//error handling...
	}
}

3.2 Save

After activating the draft, the view is rebound to the active entity.

onSave: async function () {
	try {	
		await this.oDraftManager.activateDraft();  
		await this._bindView(
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("UUID"),
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("IsActiveEntity")
		);	
	} catch (oError) {
		//error handling...
	}
}

3.3 Cancel

When canceling, the draft is discarded and the view is rebound to the active context.

onDiscard: async function () {
	try {	
		await this.oDraftManager.discardDraft();
		await this._bindView(
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("UUID"),
			this.oDraftManager.getActiveContext().getProperty("IsActiveEntity")
		);
	} catch (oError) {
		//error handling...
	}
}

4. DraftHandling and MERGE lock errors

One important learning from our projects was dealing with MERGE lock errors.
As soon as draft handling is applied to larger views with many form fields and especially rich text editors, you will sooner or later run into locking issues, as we did.

This happens because the DraftController triggers a MERGE request on every change in the view (which is correct behavior).
However, if too many changes are performed too quickly, multiple MERGE requests can be sent at the same time and end up locking each other.

This can easily be reproduced with a rich text editor in the view by pressing the Enter key very quickly. The result is a large number of lock errors (The draft itself is still updated correctly, but this can become quite annoying when working with messaging).

Our solution for this was to work with deferredGroups and changeGroups.

In order to get this to work with the DraftController and the service class, we use the merge timer provided by SAP.

First we start by setting the deferredGroup and changeGroup in the onInit function of the view controller.

this.getOwnerComponent().getModel().setDeferredGroups(["Changes"]);
this.getOwnerComponent().getModel().setChangeGroups({
  "*": {
    groupId: "Changes",
    changeSetId: "Changes",
    single: false
  }
});
this.getOwnerComponent().getModel().attachPropertyChange(this.onEnqueueSubmitChanges.bind(this, 1));

After that we define the propertyChange handler function onEnqueueSubmitChanges.

onEnqueueSubmitChanges: function (nIntervalInSeconds) {
  const mParameters = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel("util").getProperty("/ViewControl/batchParameters");
  this.oDraftManager.triggerSubmitChanges(nIntervalInSeconds, mParameters);
}

And finally, we define a new DraftManager function triggerSubmitChanges, which bundles the requests using the merge timer and submits them accordingly.

oDraftManager.prototype.triggerSubmitChanges = function (nIntervalInSeconds, mParameters) {
  const oDraftMergeTimer = this.oDraftController._oDraftMergeTimer;
  if (!oDraftMergeTimer.nTimeoutID) {
    oDraftMergeTimer.nTimeoutID = setTimeout(() => {
      oDraftMergeTimer.nTimeoutID = null;
      if (this.oModel.hasPendingChanges()) {
        this.oDraftController.triggerSubmitChanges(mParameters)
          .catch((oError) => {
            console.error("Error during submit changes:", oError);
          });
      }
    }, (nIntervalInSeconds || 0) * 1000);
  }
};

5. Conclusion

I have reduced the examples to the basics, as they can be extended as needed. We had very good experience with this service class, and draft handling in FreeStyle applications in combination with an OData V2 service worked very well.

The DraftController can of course also be used directly in the controller.
However, as mentioned before, encapsulating it is worthwhile when working with a larger application architecture, especially when testing is relevant in the project.

entry.title: Why SAP S/4HANA Go‑Lives Fail After “Success”: The Hidden Content & Attachment Layer
entry.content:
The Go‑Live That Lies

Many SAP S/4HANA programs proudly announce:
“Go‑Live successful.”

But inside IT support teams, a different story starts:

  • Vendor PDFs missing from Purchase Orders

  • GOS icons showing empty

  • ArchiveLink documents failing to open

  • SOFFCONT1 exploding in HANA

  • SRGBTBREL links broken after BP conversion

  • SYSTEM_NO_ROLL dumps during data extraction

  • HANA memory growing with no business data added

None of this appears in standard cutover checklists.

Yet this is where most post‑go‑live instability originates.

Why This Happens

SAP migration tools (SUM, Migration Cockpit, SLO, DMO, etc.) are excellent at moving:

  • Business objects

  • Tables

  • Custom code

  • Transactions

They do not validate the content layer:

Layer What SAP Migrates What It Does NOT Validate
SOFFCONT1Raw binariesOrphaned blobs, duplicates, corruption
SRGBTBRELRelationship rowsWhether links still resolve
GOSUI iconsWhether documents open
ArchiveLinkMetadataRepository integrity
KProIDsFile existence

This means:

SAP migrates pointers — not documents.

The result: a technically “successful” migration with business‑critical data silently broken.

Why ABAP Cannot Fix This at Scale

Most teams try to validate content using ABAP.

That fails because:

  • SOFFCONT1 and KPro use TBL1024 RAW data

  • Reading large binaries causes SYSTEM_NO_ROLL

  • ABAP has session memory limits

  • OData times out

  • Parallelization is weak

This is why:

2 TB of attachments can take weeks — or never complete — in ABAP.

What Actually Works

High‑volume SAP content must be validated outside SAP using:

  • RFC streaming (TBL1024 chunking)

  • External memory (Python, not ABAP)

  • Hash validation (SHA‑256)

  • Parallel workers

This allows:

  • TB‑scale extraction

  • Zero ABAP

  • No downtime

  • No production risk

This is how broken SRGBTBREL links, missing PDFs, and SOFFCONT1 bloat can be detected and repaired before they break finance, audits, and compliance.

Why CFOs Suddenly Care

When content explodes in S/4HANA:

  • Every GB = permanent HANA license cost

  • SOFFCONT1 often becomes top‑5 table

  • 30–70% of content is usually dead, orphaned, or duplicated

This turns a technical cleanup into millions in avoided HANA spend.

That is why content engineering is now a CFO‑grade migration risk — not a Basis detail.

The Missing Migration Gate

Every S/4 program should have a formal checkpoint:

“Is our content layer safe, intact, and cost‑optimized?”

If not, the go‑live is incomplete.

Final Thought

S/4HANA migrations don’t fail in Finance, SD, or MM.
They fail in what those processes depend on:
Documents, PDFs, attachments, and legal records.

Those live in the layer nobody checks.

If you are running or planning an S/4HANA conversion and have never validated SOFFCONT1, SRGBTBREL, GOS, or ArchiveLink, you are running blind — even if the system is green.

entry.title: From Automation to Agentic Ops: MCP Servers in SAP Automation Pilot
entry.content:
Nowadays, Ops teams are under increasing pressure to act faster, automate more, and collaborate with AI-driven assistants, all of that without compromising control, security, or reliability. As landscapes grow more complex, the challenge is no longer whether to automate, but how to make automation easily consumable by teammates and AI agents alike.

With tasks-specific MCP servers in SAP Automation Pilot, SAP introduces a powerful way to expose operational capabilities in a structured, manageable, and agent-friendly manner.

Typical use cases include SAP BTP operations such as Cloud Foundry Apps and SAP HANA Cloud checks, validations, diagnostics and remediations; SAP cTMS scenarios like transport validation or execution; incident management, etc. Beyond these examples, MCP Servers remain fully flexible as they can be shaped around any operational context where repeatable, governed actions are needed. This allows teams to start with well-known SAP-specific automations and gradually expand into custom, landscape-specific scenarios, relevant to their own needs.

MCP (Model Context Protocol) servers allow selected automations and content from SAP Automation Pilot to be exposed as tools. Instead of developing MCP servers by writing code or learning complex libraries, we are using the low-code/no-code capabilities of Automation Pilot, to deliver AI agents based on the needs and expectations of our Ops teams.

Why This Matters for Ops Teams

Incident handling, health checks, remediation, or maintenance activities all require different sets of actions depending on the situation and real-time systems’ state. Scenario-specific MCP servers reflect this reality by allowing Ops teams to group and expose only the automations relevant to a particular operational context. The result is an interaction model which is safe and secure for both humans and AI agents.

Because MCP servers are created using SAP Automation Pilot’s low-code / no-code capabilities, Ops teams can adapt quickly to new scenarios without writing custom APIs or services. Operational knowledge stays close to the teams who best understand their own use cases and IT resources and the agent is provided with precise tools proven to work instead of hard to assemble nuts & bolts.

From Automation to Agentic Operations

By exposing SAP Automation Pilot commands through MCP servers, operational actions become first-class capabilities that agents can consume dynamically.

This enables agentic interactions across many use cases, for example:

  • Agents can detect issues and trigger remediations;
  • DevOps and SRE teams can interact conversationally with agents;
  • Incident response becomes faster and more consistent;

Instead of navigating through multiple tools or help documents, the automations in agentic AI scenarios can be executed instantly, which dramatically reduces resolution time and manual effort.
At the same time, governance is built in. Only approved and selected automations are exposed, inputs are controlled, and every execution is auditable. This makes MCP servers suitable not just for experimentation, but for enterprise-scale production operations.

Once scenario-specific MCP servers are set up, they can be integrated seamlessly with various agent-based solutions, including also Cline and Joule (note: MCP server integration with Joule is already delivered, for more information, consult this blogpost: Agent builder in Joule Studio is now generally available: Build your own Joule agents today!).

This approach allows agents to move beyond recommendations and into real operational action without duplicating logic or skipping controls. Of course, SAP Automation Pilot remains the execution engine.

Learn More

If you would like to explore MCP servers in more detail or start using them in your own landscapes, please check out the SAP.Automation Pilot official documentation which provides further insights:

  • MCP Server Overview;
  • Managing MCP Servers;
  • Integrating SAP Automation Pilot with AI Agents;

Tasks-specific MCP servers mark an important step in the evolution from automated operations to AI agent-driven operations. If you have comments, ideas for scenarios, or topics you would like to explore further, feel free to leave a comment — your feedback is very welcome.

entry.title: How to handle OR logic in SAP GRC rules for SuccessFactors when actions contain many fields
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I am working on building GRC ruleset for SuccessFactors, and I am facing challenges related to rule design limitations.

In GRC, the rule framework does not support OR logic between fields or objects, this is standard functionality. However, this limitation becomes difficult to handle in SuccessFactors, where a single action (for example, Employee Central data) contains a very large number of fields.

Our requirement is to define rules where OR logic is needed between multiple fields within the same action (for example, access to any one of several EC data fields should trigger the rule). Without OR logic, this leads to an explosion of rules and makes maintenance complex and inefficient.

Has anyone faced a similar challenge while building GRC rules for SuccessFactors?

What approaches or best practices are recommended in such scenarios?

Are there any design patterns, workarounds, or SAP-recommended solutions to handle this effectively?
Any guidance or real-world experience would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Re: Corrective invoice template (Poland)
entry.content: In S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, template changes are done via Output Management (Maintain Form Templates app) using Adobe Forms, not classic SAPscript/SmartForms. Adobe LiveCycle Designer is used indirectly via the form template editor, but the customization scope is limited compared to on‑premise. Item grouping must be handled with conditional logic in the form.

entry.title: Re: Third Party Sales of Service with attachment
entry.content:
Yes, this is doable in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, but not fully out of the box.

Approach (high level):

  • Use a third‑party sales / bill‑through scenario where the supplier invoice amount is passed to customer billing (typically via service PO → supplier invoice → billing relevance).

  • For attaching the supplier invoice to the customer billing output:

    • Supplier invoice must be stored as an attachment (GOS / DMS / ArchiveLink).

    • Use Output Management (Adobe Form) to fetch and print or reference the attachment.

    • Automatic attachment transfer is not standard; it usually requires form logic or BTP-based extension.

In Public Cloud, limitations apply, so the recommended approach is Output Management extensibility or BTP side-by-side extension if the PDF must be embedded automatically.

entry.title: Re: SAP Version Compatibility for LOB Attachments in RAP
entry.content: Thanks @MioYasutake for the clarification. For S/4HANA 2021, native RAP LOB / stream handling is not fully supported (available from 2022 onwards), which explains the conditional If‑Match error. The recommended workaround is a hybrid approach: use RAP for business data and handle attachments via classic SEGW OData, GOS, or ArchiveLink depending on the use case.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Rename the C4C Broadcast Attachments
entry.content:
In SAP C4C / Service Cloud, the file name and Excel sheet tab name of broadcast report attachments are system‑generated and cannot be customized using standard functionality.

Key points:

  • Attachment name is generated internally (GUID-based)

  • Excel sheet tab name includes a timestamp by design

  • There is no configuration, PDI, or analytics setting to rename either of them

  • This applies to standard and custom reports

Possible workarounds:

  • Use the email subject/body to clearly mention the report name and period

  • Post-process the attachment externally (e.g. middleware, Power Automate, Outlook rule)

  • Download reports via UI/API and rename them outside C4C

  • Raise an SAP Influence / Feature Request if this is a business requirement

As of now, custom naming of broadcast attachments is not supported in C4C.

entry.title: Re: Focused Run: Early Watch Alert report as email attach...
entry.content:
In SAP Focused Run (5.1 and me.sap.com), sending the full EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) report as a PDF or HTML email attachment is not supported.

What is supported:

  • Email notifications for EWA availability

  • Emailing specific alerts/sections

  • Manual download of the full EWA report (DOCX from SAP for Me)

What is not supported (unlike Solution Manager):

  • Automatic emailing of the entire EWA report as PDF or HTML

  • Scheduling EWA as a complete email attachment to stakeholders

SAP has confirmed this limitation via:

  • Guided Answer 35654:40145

  • KBA 2930644 (EWA Troubleshooting Guide)

Workarounds:

  • Manually convert DOCX to PDF/HTML and distribute via email

  • Share EWA access links with stakeholders on SAP for Me

  • Use custom automation outside SAP (e.g. script or document workflow)

  • Submit an SAP Influence Request to request SolMan‑like functionality

As of now, there is no standard way to email the full EWA report as an attachment in Focused Run.
