entry.title: AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026) — The Change Management Blueprint
entry.content:
AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026) — The Change Management Blueprint

Part 2 of the “Practical Implementation Blueprint” series

Quick continuity from Part 1: In Part 1 (the Practical Implementation Blueprint), we focused on the foundations that make AI possible in SuccessFactors - aligning use cases to personas, getting identity and permissions right, building readiness and governance, and planning the activation roadmap across Joule, embedded AI, and extensibility. We also set a clear principle: AI suggests; humans decide.

If you haven’t read Part 1 yet, start there first:
👉Part 1 — AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Practical Implementation Blueprint

Now Part 2 goes where most programs struggle: change management - including how to enable frontline managers to confidently handle human-in-the-loop responsibilities (reviewing AI output, validating key facts, and owning final decisions). In 2026, AI in HR has moved beyond pilots; organizations are wiring AI into everyday SuccessFactors workflows through Joule and embedded capabilities. The teams that win won’t be the ones that merely “turn on” AI - they’ll be the ones that treat adoption as a product: clear outcomes, clear boundaries, and a manager-led reinforcement model.

What you’ll get in this blog

  • A practical plan to secure leadership buy-in (not just approval)
  • A manager-first adoption model (frontline managers are the adoption engine)
  • A pre-launch checklist to prepare employees before AI goes live
  • A communications cadence (pre-launch → launch → sustain)
  • An enablement model that makes AI a habit (micro-learning + in-app guidance + champions)
  • Ready-to-use templates: Trust Charter, manager talk track (with a HITL checklist), myth-vs-fact, 30-60-90 plan

0) A quick reality check: what changed in 2026

AI in SuccessFactors typically shows up in three layers:

  • Digital assistant experience (Joule): a “front door” to ask, navigate, and get guided support across workflows. Users need permission to access it (for example, “Access to Joule” in RBP).
  • Embedded AI in modules: AI-assisted experiences inside Recruiting, Learning, Performance, and other areas (depending on scope/entitlements).
  • Extensibility (Joule Studio): the layer (via SAP Build) to create and manage custom Joule agents/skills for your organization, including SAP and non-SAP workflows.

This blog is not about “turning it on.” It is about making AI stick through trust, enablement, and manager-led reinforcement.

1) Make adoption a workstream (not a side activity)

If adoption is treated as “a few emails and a training session,” usage will spike for 2–3 weeks and then fade. Treat adoption like a delivery stream with owners, deliverables, and success metrics.

Minimum adoption workstreams you need

  • Leadership sponsorship (cadence + outcome ownership)
  • Manager enablement (talk tracks + coaching + resistance handling)
  • Employee readiness (trust + safe use cases + support model)
  • Enablement (micro-learning + in-app guidance + champions)
  • Measurement (adoption + trust + value + safety signals)

Non-negotiable: If your first serious communication about AI happens after employees see it in the system, you are already late. Start manager readiness and trust messaging before launch.

2) Define outcomes + “safe scope” before you communicate

Communications and training fail when people don’t know: (1) what AI is for, (2) what it is not for, (3) what is safe to use, and (4) who remains accountable.

2.1 Outcome model (simple but measurable)

  • Experience: faster HR “how do I” answers, fewer failed attempts, higher completion rates
  • Operational: reduced HR tickets, reduced cycle time for common tasks, fewer errors
  • Manager: improved coaching consistency, faster drafting of goals/feedback (with human review)

2.2 “Safe scope” statement (trust accelerator)

  • Safe examples: navigation, policy/process Q&A, drafting text that users review and edit, learning guidance, skills exploration
  • Not in scope: sensitive decisions where humans must decide (for example, pay/promo/termination)
  • Accountability line: “AI suggests; humans decide.”

2.3 EU AI Act lens: assistive vs high-risk (EU programs)

For EU entities, map each AI use case to the EU AI Act’s risk logic. Many common uses are assistive (surfacing information, drafting content, guiding navigation) when designed for meaningful human review. However, AI used for recruitment, promotion, termination, or worker management decisions may fall into the “employment, workers’ management and access to self-employment” high-risk category (Annex III).

  • For every AI use case, document whether it is assistive/preparatory or potentially high-risk.
  • Where you conclude a use case is not high-risk, record the rationale and controls before scaling (human-in-the-loop checks, no automated decisions, limited impact).

3) Leadership buy-in: from “approval” to “ownership”

Your sponsor must do more than endorse - they must actively reinforce the new behaviors, remove blockers, and keep the program outcome-driven.

3.1 Sponsor responsibilities (keep them explicit)

  • Own outcomes: commit to 3–5 measurable outcomes (Section 2)
  • Be visible: repeated reinforcement, not a one-time kickoff message
  • Build coalition: HR + IT + Security/Privacy (+ Works Council where applicable)
  • Remove blockers: fix friction quickly (permissions, confusing outputs, gaps in help content)

3.2 Sponsor toolkit (minimum viable set)                                                                                                       

AssetPurposeWhen used
AI Vision (1 page)Why now + what outcomes we expectPre-launch
AI Guardrails (1 page)Trust boundaries + accountabilityPre-launch + launch
Sponsor cadence planMake sponsorship visible and repeatable0–90 days
Adoption dashboardSteer with evidenceMonthly

4) Frontline managers: the adoption engine (most often overlooked)

Frontline managers decide whether AI becomes “how we work” or “another feature we ignore.” Use this manager model as your operating rhythm: Communicate → Model → Assign → Coach → Reinforce.

4.1 Manager success pattern (use this as your operating rhythm)

  • Communicate the “why” and the “guardrails”
  • Model using Joule in a team setting (for example, find a policy, confirm a process)
  • Assign two starter tasks (simple, safe, high value)
  • Coach quality: “What was helpful? What wasn’t? What should we avoid?”
  • Reinforce weekly for the first month

4.2 Manager enablement kit (plug-and-play)

  • 2-minute talk track (included in Templates)
  • 5 starter tasks (examples below)
  • Myth vs Fact sheet (included in Templates)
  • Escalation path (who to contact for permissions/content/incorrect answers)
  • Coaching guide (how to reinforce habits without adding workload)

4.2A Human-in-the-loop for managers: what “good” looks like

In Part 1, we called out that “AI suggests; humans decide.” In practice, this becomes a repeatable manager habit only when you make it explicit and easy. The goal is not to slow managers down - it is to ensure AI is used safely, consistently, and with clear accountability.

Manager responsibilityWhat to do (simple rule)    When to escalate
Review AI outputScan for tone, relevance, and missing context before sharing or approving.If output is inappropriate, biased, or unsafe.
Validate key factsFor policy/process answers: verify against the official source link before acting.If the answer conflicts with policy or local legal guidance.
Own the final decisionUse AI as input; document your reasoning when decisions impact people (hiring, promotion, termination, pay).If the use case resembles automated decisioning or creates legal/compliance risk.
Use “minimum necessary” dataDon’t paste sensitive personal data into prompts; keep prompts task-focused.If users request AI to analyze highly sensitive cases.
Give feedbackReport wrong/confusing outputs so the COE can improve content, guardrails, and guidance.If issues repeat or appear systematic.

Manager shortcut: If an AI output could influence a people decision, apply this habit: Verify → Apply judgment → Decide → Document.

4.3 Five starter tasks (managers can run in 10 minutes)

  • Ask Joule where to find [policy/process] and share the correct link with the team
  • Draft your next 1:1 agenda using AI writing support, then edit it yourself
  • Draft a goal statement (you own the final version)
  • Ask “How do I complete [common manager task]?” and validate the steps
  • Share one myth you heard and validate it using the Trust Charter

5) Prepare employees before launch (trust + clarity + support)

Employees will adopt AI only if they trust boundaries and understand what is safe. Before launch, explicitly answer: What can I use it for? What should I not use it for? What data can it access? Who is accountable?

Pre-launch employee readiness checklist

  • Plain-language Trust Charter (included below)
  • Approved use-case menu (6–10 safe, high-value examples)
  • Feedback loop: how employees report wrong/confusing output
  • Support model: office hours + champions + escalation rules

6) Communications plan (pre-launch → launch → sustain)

Communication is not “one email.” It is a rhythm: trust + clarity + reinforcement, avoiding both hype and silence about guardrails.

Phase
TimingAudienceMessage focusChannels
Pre-launchT-4 to T-1 weeksLeaders + ManagersWhy, outcomes, guardrails, manager roleEmail, leadership briefing, manager call
LaunchWeek 0Pilot cohortStart-here tasks + support + feedback loopIn-app banner, Teams/Slack, short demo
StabilizeWeeks 1–4Pilot + managersConfidence building, myth-busting, early winsOffice hours, tips, manager nudges
ScaleWeeks 5–12Next cohortsProof (metrics), champions, reinforcementTownhall mention, FAQ refresh, in-app guidance

7) Enablement model: verified AI literacy + in-workflow support

AI adoption rarely scales through classroom training alone; people need micro-learning, in-workflow guidance, performance support, and champions.

7.1 Verified AI literacy (especially important in EU programs)

Build AI literacy into your plan from Day 0. For EU programs, treat AI literacy as a formal enablement item - not an afterthought.

7.2 Enablement components (recommended minimum)

  • Employees: 10–15 minutes micro-learning + safe use cases + Trust Charter
  • Managers: talk track + starter tasks + coaching guide
  • HR/COE: governance, content quality loop, escalation handling
  • In-app guidance: task walkthroughs for complex processes
  • Office hours: weekly for first month

7.3 Tooling that supports adoption

  • SAP Enable Now: enablement content to drive adoption and productivity
  • Digital adoption platforms: on-screen walkthroughs, nudges, and analytics to see where processes stall
  • Joule: “help in the moment” for navigational and how-to support (when properly governed)

30-60-90 rollout plan with gates (don’t scale without them)

Day 0–30: Trust + habit formation (pilot)

  • Launch to a controlled cohort (example: 100–500 users)
  • Weekly office hours + track top 10 questions
  • Publish “Top 10 safe use cases” and refine weekly
  • Manager nudges: 2 starter tasks/week + 7-day check-in

Day 31–60: Stabilize + expand

  • Expand only when gates are met (below)
  • Introduce additional use cases based on value + safety
  • Strengthen in-app guidance where drop-offs occur

Day 61–90: Scale + operationalize

  • Move to COE rhythm: monthly adoption review + governance
  • Quarterly enablement refresh (new use cases + refreshed trust messaging)
  • Shift from “project” to “product” operating model

Adoption gates (example)

  • Trust signal: fewer “is this safe?” questions + sentiment improving
  • Repeat usage: repeat users increasing week-over-week
  • Manager engagement: managers completing starter tasks + coaching teams
  • Escalation health: issues logged + resolution time improving

9) Measure adoption beyond “usage”

Usage alone is not success. Track adoption, trust, value, and safety together.

9.1 Suggested AI adoption KPI set (pilot-ready)

 

DimensionMetricDescriptionPilot target example
AdoptionActive Joule users (7/30 days)Unique users issuing AI queries in a given window40–60% of pilot
AdoptionRepeat usersUsers active in at least 3 weeks out of 4Upward trend weekly
ValueTicket deflectionReduction in HR support tickets for “how do I” topics10–25% reduction
ValueTime-to-completeMedian completion time for 3–5 frequent transactions20–40% reduction
TrustConfidence / sentiment scorePulse: “I understand what is safe and I trust boundaries”>75% favorable
SafetyPermission boundary incidentsEscalations about access/scope issuesFlat or decreasing
ComplianceEU risk assessment coverageAI use cases assessed and documented (assistive vs high-risk)100% of relevant

10) Templates (copy/paste)

10.1 The AI Trust Charter (employee-facing)

The AI Trust Charter

  • Data privacy: we apply enterprise controls to protect confidential information.
  • Security: AI can only access connected data sources within your authorizations/permissions.
  • Accountability: AI is a tool, not a decision-maker. Humans remain accountable for sensitive decisions.
  • Transparency + feedback: we communicate where AI is used and how to report outputs that are unclear or incorrect.

10.2 Myth vs Fact (employee comms)

MythFact
“AI can see my private chats.”False. AI access depends on connected systems and your permissions/authorizations.
“AI will decide who gets promoted.”False. AI may support insights, but humans remain accountable for decisions.
“If AI suggests it, it must be correct.”False. AI outputs require human judgment and validation; use the feedback loop to report issues.
“If I don’t use AI, I’ll be left behind.”Partly true. AI literacy is becoming a core workplace skill - which is why enablement and safe use cases are provided.

10.3 Manager talk track (2 minutes) + HITL checklist

1) Why we’re doing this:
We’re introducing AI support in SuccessFactors to simplify HR work and free time for coaching and value-added work.

2) What it is (and isn’t):
It helps with guidance and productivity. It does not replace human decisions in sensitive areas.

3) What I need you to do:
Try the two starter tasks this week and share what worked / what didn’t. If something looks wrong, use the feedback channel.

4) The HITL checklist (use this when AI output touches people decisions):
- Verify key facts (policy/process)
- Apply judgment (context + fairness)
- Decide (you own the outcome)
- Document (why the decision was made)

5) Where to get help:
Use office hours, our champions, and in-app help. Escalate issues quickly — we will fix them.

10.4 Sponsor 30-60-90 template

Sponsor Outcome: ________________________________
Success Metrics (3-5): ___________________________

Day 0-30:
- Visible sponsorship moment(s): _________________
- Barriers removed: ______________________________
- Reinforcement message delivered: ________________

Day 31-60:
- Cohort expansion decision (go/no-go): ___________
- Adoption review (trust + usage + issues): ________
- Recognition plan: _______________________________

Day 61-90:
- Move to COE/product operating model: ____________
- Quarterly enablement refresh: ___________________

Final note: treat AI as a product, not a project

The goal isn’t go-live; the goal is habit, trust, and measurable value. The organizations that win in 2026 will treat AI in SAP SuccessFactors as a product: continuously improving approved use cases, strengthening enablement, reinforcing manager behaviors, and measuring outcomes.

Coming next (Part 3): A practical AI Adoption Operating Model - COE structure, cadence, backlog, governance, and release-alignment.

entry.title: Re: the CDS of APP Display Actual Costing Result
entry.content:
Are you asking about the CDS view behind the app?

if thats the query then its I_ActualCostingRunResult

This is a Query category CDS view that aggregates data for the actual costing results. It is built upon several foundational system tables and views to provide a comprehensive look at the costing run outcomes. This can be used for reporting purpose.

Depending on exactly which data you are trying to extract from the "Actual Costing" logic, you may also find these related CDS views useful:

I_ActlCostgMatlValueChainItem is a fact view Used for the Material Value Chain display (visualizing the flow of costs).

I_ActualCostingActivityResult is a fact view which focuses on the activity data (cost centers/activities) within the actual costing run.

I_ML_BALANCE Is a consumption view 

Often used to check actual costs for materials in a balance summary format.

hope this helps.

Best Regards,

Bidisha

entry.title: Improve Build Apps UIs to Allow Keyboard Click / Control Focus
entry.content:
I was doing this great tutorial by my colleagues @Rekha_DR and @shrinivasan_neelamegam about creating a chatbot using Build Apps and AI Core, a topic they delivered in the SAP TechEd developer keynote in 2024: https://github.com/SAP-samples/teched2024-developer-keynote/blob/main/topics/DEV100A-build-chatbot-apps-aicore/README.md

It worked perfectly. 

The tutorial let you create a chatbot where you typed a prompt, got an answer, and then could send a new prompt, like a regular chatbot. (By the way, one of the clever designs of theirs was that the context of the conversation was always sent back to the AI Core with every subsequent prompt.)

I thought what would make the app even more helpful would be:

  • To be able to press Enter after typing in each prompt.
  • To place the cursor automatically in the prompt input box so the user could just start typing the next prompt.

 

Allow Enter Instead of Button Click

To do this, you first want to create a custom event for the logic that you want connected to the button click / Enter press.

Drag a Receive Event flow function onto the canvas.

Set the Event Source to Fired from "Trigger Event", and give the event a name, like SendChat.

Attach your logic (in this case the calls to AI Core) to the event.

Now all that's left is to trigger this event when the user clicks the button, or presses Enter. 

For the button click, select the button click, drag a Trigger Event flow function, and connect it to your Component Tap event for the button.

Configure the Trigger Event flow function by selecting your new event to be triggered.

To enable the logic to be triggered by pressing Enter, highlight your input box, and create the following logic on the input box's onKeyPress event.

To the onKeyPress event, add an If Condition flow function with the following formula:

outputs["Receive event"].eventValue == "Enter"

And then to the top output add a Trigger Event, configured the same as for the button click logic above.

 

Place Cursor in Input Box

Every time I send a prompt, I want the cursor to return to the input box so I can type in the next prompt.

Install the Focus Input flow function from the Marketplace.

After the logic for sending the prompt and receiving the answer from AI Core, add this flow function and specify the input box.

😽

entry.title: Re: Java VM Settings to avoid memory leaks
entry.content: JVM settings alone cannot prevent memory leaks. However, JVM settings can influence the timeframe in which memory problems can arise. In a dedicated NetWeaver AS Java system with 16 GB of physical memory, using a 4 GB Java heap is relatively conservative. If there is sufficient memory available in your operating system,  then in that case, you can go ahead and try increasing  the heap size to 6-8 GB. However, a recurring out-of-memory condition indicates a likely heap or off-heap memory leak rather than simply insufficient heap size. Analyzing GC logs to verify whether old generation memory is reclaimed after a Full GC and capturing heap dumps to identify retained objects are essential steps. Proper diagnosis and fixing the underlying cause is more effective than relying solely on JVM memory tuning to avoid memory leaks.  For a deeper understanding of common signs of a Java memory leak, identifying memory leaks by analyzing a heap dump, check out this blog,  From Symptoms to Solutions: Troubleshooting Java Memory Leaks & OutOfMemoryError.

We are facing a scenario where multiple inbound delivery (IBD) line items are referencing the same PO line item. IBD is created via EDI and partial GR is posted via IDOC. The goods movement is posted successfully using BAPI_GOODSMVT_CREATE. However, only one IBD item can be completed, while the remaining IBD item stays in status A (not yet processed).

For example:

PO A item 10 - qty 100

IBD item 10 - PO A item 10 - qty 60 -> GR status C

IBD item 20 - PO A item 10 - qty 40 -> GR status A

I would like to understand:

1. Is this behavior standard SAP design?

2. Is there any standard configuration or recommended approach for this case?

any guidance or best practice recommendation would be highly appreciated.

Thanks

entry.title: Re: the CDS of APP Display Actual Costing Result
entry.content:
Hi @omega-ou 

The released CDS view I_ActlCostgMatlValueChainItem can show all material movements data as those in CKM3N (material price analysis). When using this CDS view, you are required to enter costing run ID, please use I_ActCostingRunTypeVH for the costing run value help.
